caption:
This photograph features a close-up view of a mailbox mounted on a metal post. The mailbox is traditional in design, primarily rectangular, with a curved top and a front that includes a door with a small, horizontal handle for opening. It is weathered with a metallic finish that showcases various signs of wear and exposure to elements.

Above the mailbox, there is a distinct and decorative sign that adds a personalized, rustic charm to the scene. The sign is crafted from black metal and depicts a scene of a farmer, wearing a hat, plowing a field with a horse. The scene is framed within the outline of a nameplate that reads "W. H. CORNELL," suggesting this is the name of the property or mailbox owner.

The background of the photograph is softly blurred, providing a contrast that highlights the mailbox and sign. The background color tone is greenish-gray, likely indicating grass or a garden in soft focus, which suggests a rural or semi-rural setting.

The overall composition of the photograph effectively draws attention to the mailbox and the decorative sign, emphasizing a theme of rural life and personalization in everyday objects.
title: Mailbox on Sims Road at Robertstown, Georgia, a mile northeast of Helen. This low mountain area some 90 miles northeast of Atlanta attracts campers and fishermen. Also of interest is the business district in Helen which has been Renovated with a Bavarian-Alpine theme. Success of the project, begun in 1969, has led to new development which will affect both towns. A planning report for Helen cites the need for balance between growth and public interest.
